conversation.content: [very quietly] Six years. [pause] He actually said that to me. After six years of—of everything. [bitter] "You'll never have the natural talent." [laugh] Like he couldn't have mentioned this, I don't know, five and a half years ago? [angry] Before I spent every weekend in that workshop, before I missed my sister's wedding to finish that commission, before I— [sigh] [upset] God, I can still smell the sawdust on my clothes. [very sad] Maybe he's right though. [hesitantly] Maybe I've been fooling myself this whole time. [anxious] I mean, my joints never fit perfectly on the first try like Marcus's do. [frustrated] But I thought that was just, um... I thought that came with time. [shaky voice] Six years. [long pause] [furious] You know what? No. [confidently] Natural talent? [sarcastic] Oh, I'm sorry, was natural talent there at four in the morning fixing his mistakes on the Henderson cabinet? [passionate] Was natural talent the one who figured out how to salvage that walnut shipment he ruined? [very loudly] I've earned my place in that workshop! [pause] [very quietly] Haven't I? [sigh] [exhausted] I don't even know anymore.

subject: The master craftsman whose workshop you've been apprenticing at for six years just told you that you'll never have the natural talent needed
